bibl.title: Chin Quock Wah vs. Henry M. White. Criminal.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK Wah for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. ) NO. 2971. ASSIGNMENT OF ERRORS.

Comes JOHN J. SULLIVAN, and as Attorney for the petitioner and appellant in the above entitled cause, says: That in the record and proceeding in this case, and in the Order and Judgment entered on the twenty-ninth day of May, 1915, there is manifest errors in this, to wit:
I. That the Court erred in refusing to grant the Writ of Habeas Corpus, and discharge the petitioner.
II. That the Court erred in admitting in evidence the so-called record marked "Exhibit A" without further proof than the certificate thereunto appended.

III. That the Court erred in ruling that the so-called record marked "Exhibit A" was to the effect that CHIN QUOCK WAH had been granted a full and fair hearing on his application to land in the United States.

IV. That the Court erred in ruling that the so-called record marked "Exhibit A" proved that the petitioner had been accorded the right to appeal from the excluding decision, and that said appeal had been heard and decided in a fair and legal manner, in accordance with the rules and regulations governing the admission of Chinese into the United States.

V. That the Court erred in overruling counsel for petitioner that inasmuch as said so-called "Exhibit A" contained no written decision or order signed by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, it did not appear therefrom that the appeal had been duly acted upon by the United States.

VI. That the Court erred in ruling that the so-called "Exhibit A" proved that a proper record on appeal had been submitted to, and acted upon by the officers authorized by law to act, under and by virtue of the rules and regulations governing admission of Chinese into the United States, and the right to appeal from an adverse decision by the Commissioner at the Port of Entry.

VII. That the Court erred in refusing to rule as requested by counsel for petitioner, that the memorandum for the Assistant Secretary included in said record made by the Commissioner-General of Immigration, or under his authority, and was not evidence, was not given under oath as shown by the record, and should not have been made a part of the record or admissable.

VIII. That the Court erred in ruling that the so-called record marked "Exhibit A", conclusively proved that the petitioner had been accorded a fair hearing, both at the port of entry and on appeal, in accordance with the law and treaty between the United States and China, and rules and regulations governing the admission of Chinese, and that there was evidence to substantiate the findings of the Department.

IX. That the Court erred in refusing to rule that no one but the -2-
Secretary of Commerce and Labor has a right to affirm an excluding decision.

X. That the Court erred in refusing to rule that letters, etc. from officials to the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, and to the Department were not evidence, not given under oath, contained private opinions, and were not admissable, and should not be considered by the officials of the Department in determining the decision in this case.
XI. That the Court erred in refusing to rule that there was nothing in the record to show that the Assistant Secretary had been authorized to act.

XII. That the Court erred in refusing to rule that the record showed such unfairness and illegality as to warrant the Court to investigate the status, or dispose of the case as law and justice required, omitting therefrom such evidence as should not have been admissible.

XIII. That the Court erred in not ruling that the McGettrick certificate issued July ninth, 1896 to the alleged father of the petitioner, and made a part of the record, was not "res adjudicata" of his citizenship.

XIV. That the Court erred in not ruling and finding that teh status of the alleged father was made on his trip to China, and his return therefrom in January, 1914, as a merchant and citizen of the United States.

XV. That the Court erred in not finding that the petitioner was -3-
a minor son of CHIN WING HIN, and a minor son of a Chinese merchant, and a minor son of a citizen of the United States, and therefore should be allowed to land.

XVI. That the Court erred in rendering a Decree, discharging the Writ of Habeas Corpus, and remanding the petitioner to the custody of the officerst of the United States, and depriving him of his liberty.
XVII. That said order entered on the twenty-ninth day of May, 1915 is not warranted by, nor supported by the facts of the law in the premises, but is contrary thereto,

WHEREFORE, said CHIN QUOCK WAH, the petitioner and appellant herein, by and through his Attorney, JOHN J. SULLIVAN, prays that his Assignment of Errors be entered upon the record in this case, and that upon the hearing o fthis appeal it may be adjudged by the United States Supreme Court, and that the Order and Judgment on the twenty-ninth day of May, 1915 made and entered, be in all things reversed, set aside and held for naught, and that it be adjudged and decreed that the petitioner and appellant have an adjudication in his favor, as prayed for in said amended petition.
BY AND THROUGH
NO. 2971 ORIGINAL
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT STATE OF WASHINGTON KING COUNTY
In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK WAH, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus Plaintiff vs. Defendant
ASSIGNMENT OF ERRORS
BEELER & SULLIVAN LAWYERS 510-11 WHITE BUILDING SEATTLE, WASH.
FILED IN THE U. S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION JUN101915
div1.ab: FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk By Ed M Lakin Deputy 2x
